etymology.description: 阳(陽 ‘male; yang’) + 具 ‘implement; organ’ = male genitals.
etymology.interpretation: Combines the notion of masculinity/yang (阳) with an implement/organ (具) to denote the male sexual organ. Neutral in technical contexts but can sound blunt or vulgar in casual speech.
etymology.simplification: 陽 → 阳 by replacing the phonetic 昜 with 日 under the 阝 radical to reduce strokes and regularize the 阴/阳 pair; 具 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 医生检查患者的阳具(醫生檢查患者的陽具)，确认没有外伤(確認沒有外傷)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng jiǎnchá huànzhě de yángjù, quèrèn méiyǒu wàishāng.
examples.english: The doctor examined the patient's male genitals and confirmed there was no external injury.

examples.chinese: 在解剖学课程中(在解剖學課程中)，老师讲解阳具的结构与功能(老師講解陽具的結構與功能)。
examples.pinyin: Zài jiěpōuxué kèchéng zhōng, lǎoshī jiǎngjiě yángjù de jiégòu yǔ gōngnéng.
examples.english: In anatomy class, the teacher explained the structure and function of the male genitals.

examples.chinese: 在某些场合(在某些場合)，这个词显得粗俗(這個詞顯得粗俗)，应谨慎使用(應謹慎使用)。
examples.pinyin: Zài mǒuxiē chǎnghé, zhège cí xiǎnde cūsú, yīng jǐnshèn shǐyòng.
examples.english: In some settings, the term sounds vulgar and should be used with caution.
